name: belgand
text: Face it, but Molly is rocking a pretty decent set of cleavage there. Not the sort of thing we normally see, but that is all kinds of all right. If she did not have a cat head you would be lining up to get your bone on.

name: luckypyjamas
text: the internet has basically rendered cleavage meaningless.

name: belgand
text: Not to the connoisseur. Plus, regardless of the Internet there is still a girl whose tits you want to see that is not likely to be topless on the Internet. She is right in front of you. You cannot resist.

text: MY BONE LINES UP BEHIND NO MAN

name: dusty
text: He goes here and there they say. Disguised as a muscular oiled up sailor in cuttoffs. Speak not of him, always he may be listening.

name: belgand
text: Yet simultaneously awesome. That is the duality in which greatness lives. Sitting astride the thing razor that separates horror and joy.

name: cheeks_jd
text: Or not a fan of John Mellencamp. Crazy I know but it happens.

name: arbys
text:
Or not watch MTV/VH1/whatever.

I doubt I've seen much more than a dozen music videos in my life, and most of those were on the Interwebs.

name: tagrineth
text: The sandwich speaks the truth!  I'm even a fan of Mellencamp but I never really watch music videos unless someone points out a specific one on YouTube for me to watch.

name: lucid
text:
I'd never seen the video but I still got it because of the clap section in the song.

And I was born in '82.

name: greenkoolayd
text: it was a good year, indeed...

name: trollcollins
text:
But wouldn't you seek out the videos by bands and artists that you love?

You're not one of those "I don't like music" freaky people are you?

name: comrade_tom
text: What is up with those people?

name: st_elmos_fire
text:
They're crazzzy that's what craaaaaazzzzyyy

oh, and they probably have hearts made of cold cold steel, or something worse, cause even then they could probably dig some electro

name: tagrineth
text: Not everyone even likes music videos.  I don't really care for them myself unless they're really artistic or tell a story that really matches the song - like, one of my favourite music videos is Eyes of the Insane.

name: trollcollins
text: A comment left by trollcollins was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by Triptaphane, apocowarg, Jewpacabra, spicyponyhead)

name: tagrineth
text: My point is simply that not everyone is going to go looking for music videos.  Following your example, I only got hooked on achewood because a friend linked me to it.  Same with Eyes of the Insane.  ^^;

name: stereo
text:
The basic thing I know about music is that it is sound.

Man now I'm all imagining a blind person reading Achewood. Hilarious !

name: selbencoirlo
text: This post implies that you are deaf, which makes your user name ironic. Unless it's referring to stereovision, in which case it's not ironic. Unless you have one eye, in which case it's ironic again.

name: cracklewater
text:
Read "The Case Against Art" by the Reverend J. Bufo.

'Tis a powerful argument.

name: area_homosexual
text:
What sucks is having a childhood assertion corroborated by the intermanet about 20 years too late to save you from being called "a bullshitter" in elementary school.
Hey, here's a youtube video of that version of super mario 1 with different monsters. And here's that episode of Inspector Gadget where Penny asks Brain to "drop a deuce" on an unconcious MAD villain. I guess I wasn't lying. But still, too little, too late there, internet.

name: straw
text: Seriously, some guy came up to me the other day talking about this holocaust thing and I was all "WHAAAAAAAAAA?"

name: sje46
text: A 15 year old girl I know doesn't know what the Holocaust is.

name: area_homosexual
text: "It's when you predict the virtual value of a thing, isn't it? Like, you know, the, like hologrammy, holograph... cost of it? Like how shooting stars have a holocost of like, a jillion dollars?"

name: sje46
text: "wait, a jillion is more than a billion, right?"

text:
I've moved on to denying the entire Second World War.

name: blarghamagarky
text: Isn't it bizarre that kids almost our age were born in the 1990s. I feel like if someone says they are born in 1990 or on they are not a real person yet this is a very hypocritical thought to have

name: heccibiggs
text: I'm so with you on this one. Most of my friends from my year at school were born in either 88 or 89, so when I became good friends with some people in the year below me, it didn't occur until it was actually pointed out that most of them were born in 1990. Fucking weird. They're like babies, surely?

name: zeal
text: It blew my mind to encounter children born in the mid 90s, or even in the 00s.  It was too much, too fast.

name: achilleselbow
text: You are all weird. Everyone knows that 84 was the last good year to be born in. If you were born after that, you missed the whole era when people would say something sarcastically and then add "...NOT!" after a few seconds. Nowadays everyone just takes that "NOT" for granted. Damn kids. Stay out of my driveway!

name: blarghamagarky
text: My sister was born in '84. She has tacky blue eye shadow and too many babies

name: tekende
text:
Hell yes! Born in '84s represent!

Plus, you know, 1984 is the title of that one book by that Orwell fellow.

name: bixschmix
text: I was born merely days into 85. Can I squeeze into the cool club? My mom likes to remind me that I was due weeks before Christmas.

name: alzuna
text: We can have our own cool club man, 1985 was where it was AT.

name: lucobrazzi88
text: i said not after many things growing up but sadly by that time "PSYCH!" was becoming just as popular.

name: charchar
text: I was born in 1990.  My musical tastes are focused in the 80s and 20s, though.  Whole damn 21st century hasn't been much more than television, homework, and unrequited crushes, and can therefore fuck off.

text: that is an unjustly sweeping statement and thus prone to being highly incorrect!

text:
I am a nerd. Also, I suck at technology. This has been Twitchy People Lashing Out Unwisely

text:
1990? shame, Calvin harris will have no hugs for you.

none whatsoever

name: smilebuddha
text: Nineteen Hundred and Seventy Six was a fine year to be born.  I remember seeing E.T. and Raiders Of The Lost Ark in theaters.  I also remember Ronald Reagan, and watching the Challenger explode on live television. And we had better, heavier, metal and plastic toys.  So there.

name: mattylite
text:
Figure 12: Better, Heavier Metal and Plastic Toy

[IMGS OFF]

name: cpnglxynchos
text: O, I C!

name: woodenteeth
text: 1976. Good year. Well-rounded. Full-bodied (especially now that we're in our thirties). Spoiler Alert: Your Metabolism Slows the Fuck Down.

name: woodenteeth
text: Oh. And you seem to have lied in your profile. 34?

name: smilebuddha
text: No lie...I just would like to blame Assetbar, that cad.  Faulty math fixed.

name: woodenteeth
text: Did that cad even get you a birthday present? (I assume that it was recently). I have a month before I join thee. Good luck.

name: invidious
text: Where do I sign up to join this 1976 club.  Do we get special perks like breastmen?  What if you're a member of both?

name: invidious
text: Please note that the first sentence in my prior post was evidently not a question, but a demand.

name: hbaranov
text: Screw you old gits. 1990 2nd August. Me and Saddam is chillin yo. Born on the day of Invasion. My mother calls me AntiChrist. You can call me Sir.

name: sharktastic
text: I was born in 1974. I remember the FIRST VIDEO EVER. ("Video Killed the Radio Star" by The Buggles). Of course, that was back in the day when MtV played videos...

name: woodenteeth
text: Fuck dude... Prince ruled through most of the 80's. What's wrong with you.

name: belgand
text:
Sounds like someone never heard of Sonic Youth, Metallica (when they were good), Iron Maiden, Pixies, Nirvana (formed in the 80s dammit), Dinosaur Jr., Husker Du....

Face it man, there was a ton of great music in the 80s. It's not all just pop crap that the rest of us only like because we have strongly nostalgic memories of it.

name: invidious
text: Rush was still good in the 80s.

name: belgand
text: I would never speak ill of Rush, but I still consider them more 70s going on to further success in the early 80s.

name: blarghamagarky
text: I was born shortly after Jack and Diane yet I am from America and my dad did drive a Ford Bronco during one of the important developmental stages of my childhood thus I know more Mellencamp than a young lady should

text:
Before I ever saw this one, I pictured Diane looking pretty much exactly like Molly does here.

Also, I will offer a large sum of money to whomever can make me a "dark box" like the one pictured.

text: We will all in our own times reside within boxes full of darkness.

name: hbaranov
text: Take one box. Place in one room. Light with dim lights. Use extremely black tinted glass. Clap hands in white gloves. Serve for two.

text: To quote my mother, may she rest in peace, "That cat has some bodacious ta-tas."

text:
Quoting your dead mother's comment on tits.

You sir, are chubbied.

text: Please tell me your mother was in fact referring to this comic. Because any other situation involving that quote would be just awful.

text: Boo to you. Mothers can be very very hilarious. Not all are cookie wielding, kercheif cleaning Woman's Day readers.

text:
My grandma always calls a "gazebo" a "gah-zebra"

In comparison to what your mom said though, mine is less sad and less funny at the same time.

text: I recently learned that this song was number one on the charts the day I was born. Now, more than ever, Beef and Molly are my OTP.

text: The first time I read this comic I didn't get the joke.  Years later I go back and finally understand.  The clouds have cleared.

text: Fools Rush In (Can't Help Falling in Love)from Elvis as the soundtrack to Beef's wedding beat down of Showbiz.  She's Got You from Patsy Cline as Ray's ring tone.

name: gournal
text: You'll probably want Heaven by Talking Heads even if it technically wasn't played by the characters, it was kind of the theme for the arc when Beef dies.
